Name: Security Policy Guidelines
Description: Define high-level security expectations for the organization. Explain what must be protected and why.

Name: Information Security Policies
Description: Master document containing all organizational security policies. Includes compliance and enforcement requirements. Procedures are documented separately.

Name: Acceptable Use Policy (AUP)
Description: Defines how systems may be used, including networks, internet, messaging, and devices. Helps reduce liability and misuse.

Name: Business Continuity
Description: Plans to maintain operations during disruptions. May include manual or alternate workflows. Must be documented and tested regularly.

Name: Disaster Recovery Plan (DRP)
Description: Focuses on restoring IT systems after a disaster. Includes alternate site planning, backup/recovery, and staff availability considerations.

Name: Security Incidents & Examples
Description: Include malware execution, phishing, ransomware, DDoS attacks, and unauthorized access or data theft.

Name: Incident Response Roles
Description: Security management: oversight and authority. Compliance/legal: regulatory compliance. Technical staff: investigation and restoration. Users: report suspicious activity.

Name: SDLC (Software Development Lifecycle)
Description: Framework for developing and maintaining software. Security integration (DevSecOps) ensures protection across waterfall, agile, or DevOps models.

Name: Change Management
Description: Structured process for modifying configurations. Includes approval, scheduling, testing, and rollback plans to avoid system disruption.

Name: Onboarding
Description: Create user accounts, assign permissions, issue equipment, and ensure policy acknowledgment.

Name: Offboarding
Description: Disable accounts, revoke access, retrieve company assets, and document separation activities.

Name: Playbooks
Description: Documented response steps for specific incidents such as phishing or malware infection.

Name: SOAR (Security Orchestration, Automation, Response)
Description: Automates security responses and integrates tools for faster coordinated incident handling.

Name: Governance
Description: Structures such as committees guide security strategy and enforce accountability.

Name: Centralized vs Decentralized Governance
Description: Centralized: decisions made by one authority. Decentralized: distributed decision-making across groups or regions.

Name: Laws, Regulations & Standards
Description: SOX ensures financial integrity; HIPAA protects health data. Legal teams handle evidence, breach notifications, and compliance.

Name: Industry-Specific Requirements
Description: Utilities, medical, and financial industries may require enhanced regulatory compliance and control frameworks.

Name: Geographic vs Global Security
Description: Regional laws differ globally, especially regarding data storage and privacy (e.g., GDPR).

Name: Data Roles & Responsibilities
Description: Owner defines and classifies data; Controller determines purpose; Processor handles data; Custodian maintains security and compliance.

Name: Risk Assessments
Description: Ad hoc: when needed. Recurring: scheduled. Qualitative: judgment-based. Quantitative: uses numerical metrics (AV, EF, ARO).

Name: Quantitative Risk Metrics
Description: SLE = AV × EF. ALE = ARO × SLE. These measure financial impact of security risks.

Name: Risk Concepts
Description: Impact: life, safety, finances. Likelihood: chance of occurrence. Risk appetite: acceptable risk level. Tolerance: deviation range.

Name: Risk Register
Description: Tracks risk details including ownership, severity, mitigation, and monitoring indicators.

Name: Risk Response Strategies
Description: Transfer (insurance), Accept, Avoid, or Mitigate. Exceptions may allow deviation from standard controls.

Name: Business Recovery Metrics
Description: RTO: target restore time. RPO: acceptable data loss. MTTR: mean time to repair. MTBF: mean time between failures.

Name: Vendor and Supply Chain Management
Description: Includes right-to-audit, internal/external audits, and due diligence before vendor approval.

Name: Vendor Monitoring
Description: Ongoing evaluation of vendor performance, compliance, and security posture.

Name: Vendor Questionnaires
Description: Used to assess vendor risk, compliance status, and contractual obligations.

Name: Agreements & Contracts
Description: Include SLA, MOU, MOA, MSA, SOW, NDA, and BPA to define roles, expectations, and confidentiality.

Name: Compliance & Privacy
Description: Ensures adherence to laws, policies, and regulations. Noncompliance may result in fines or penalties.

Name: GLBA (Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act)
Description: Protects consumer financial data and enforces privacy safeguards for institutions.

Name: GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation)
Description: EU privacy law granting individuals control over personal data collection and processing.

Name: Data Subject
Description: The individual whose personal data is collected, stored, or processed.

Name: Cybersecurity Audits & Attestation
Description: Audits evaluate control effectiveness; attestation confirms accuracy of results. Can be internal or external.

Name: Reconnaissance
Description: Passive: collect public information. Active: direct interaction (e.g., scanning) to identify vulnerabilities.

Name: Phishing Campaigns
Description: Used to train employees and measure awareness. Teaches users to recognize and report social engineering attempts.

Name: Security Awareness Team
Description: Develops, maintains, and communicates training materials and awareness programs.

Name: User Behavior & Awareness Training
Description: Covers password hygiene, social engineering, data handling, remote work safety, and insider threat awareness.
